examples.en: I bought a charm at the shrine to help fulfill my heart’s desires.
examples.ja: 私はその神社で心願成就の御札を買いました。

examples.en: This amulet has the magical power to fulfill any heartfelt wish.
examples.ja: このおまもりは、どのような心願も成就させる魔法のおまもりです。

examples.en: At this temple, they perform daily fire rituals called "goma" to pray for the fulfillment of people's heartfelt desires.
examples.ja: このお寺では、毎日護摩を焚いて、人々の心願を祈願しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The thing your <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>request</kanji>s is what your heart wants. This is your <vocabulary>heartfelt desire</vocabulary>.

心願 is often found in the phrase 心願成就 (fulfillment of a heartfelt wish), commonly used in the context of prayer rituals at Shinto shrines or Buddhist temples.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Viet was chuckling softly to himself, especially when Koichi was yelling.
examples.ja: 取り分けコウイチがどなっている時に、ビエトは一人静かに笑っていました。

examples.en: I finally passed JLPT N1 and I'm especially appreciative of Tofugu for that.
examples.ja: ついにJLPT1に合格したんですが、トーフグには取り分け感謝しています。

examples.en: It’s not especially cold today.
examples.ja: 今日は取り分け寒いという訳ではない。

meaning_mnemonic:
You 取り (take) and then 分け (divide) something. But you'll want to be <vocabulary>especially</vocabulary> careful not to give anyone an unequal share. This is especially important because we’re dealing with money, and people will flip out and shoot you under the table if you aren't especially accurate.

Note that this word is usually written in kana.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words 取る and 分ける. So long as you know those words you should be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: Long ago, Japanese women had more rights than men did.
examples.ja: 遠い昔、日本は女権社会でした。

examples.en: People whose Twitter account names have a shrimp emoji are feminists.
examples.ja: ツイッターのアカウント名にエビの絵文字がついている人は、フェミニスト（女権主義者）です。

examples.en: Unlike the West, Japan does not have a history of strong women’s rights movements.
examples.ja: 西洋と違い、日本では歴史上、大きな女権拡張運動は起きていない。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>woman</kanji>'s <kanji>rights</kanji> consist of <vocabulary>women's rights</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word that is often used at the beginning of compounds, such as 女権拡張運動 (movement for the expansion of women's rights). In everyday conversations, you can just say 女性の権利 to talk about women’s rights.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There is a mountain called Tsurugidake, which literally means Mt. Sword, in Toyama prefecture.
examples.ja: 富山県には、剣の山という意味の、剣岳と呼ばれる山があります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>peak</kanji> of the mountain is a <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mountain</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you climb to the top of the <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary>, you're so amazed to find vegetation at this altitude. The only thing that grows here, and in thick amounts, is <reading>竹</reading> (たけ). It is impeding your progress to the very top of the peak, in fact, which is a bother. It's as if it's guarding something...

examples.en: Petticoats prevent skirts from rubbing against your skin.
examples.ja: ペティコートは、スカートが肌と擦れることを防ぎます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is an intransitive version of 擦る, so it means <vocabulary>to be rubbed</vocabulary>. It often implies damage, in which case it can mean <vocabulary>to be grazed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be scraped</vocabulary>, like when your knee gets grazed against a rough wall.
reading_mnemonic:
You really don’t want your knee <vocabulary>to be grazed</vocabulary>. If it happens, you are gonna <reading>sue</reading> (す). But the <reading>cos</reading>t (こす) of suing is pretty high, so be careful not to get grazed in the first place!

Depending on which reading you use, the nuance changes slightly. For example, すれる is the usual choice when you’re talking about your grazed knees or worn out jeans. For other uses, they are often interchangeable.

examples.en: "Did you just spill coffee on the carpet?" "Oh no! Sorry." "If sorry fixed everything, we wouldn’t need the police!"
examples.ja: 「あんた、今カーペットに珈琲を零したでしょう？」「しまった!ごめん!」「ごめんで済んだら警察はいらないわよ！」

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>zero</kanji>, but the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to spill something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to drop something</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, if you spill something, eventually it will reach <kanji>zero</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine you're <reading>co-bo</reading>iling (こぼ) water with someone. With the two of you co-boiling, the water is boiling pretty hard. Watch out, though — you're about <reading>to spill</reading> the hot water everywhere!

examples.en: After taking a shower, she was staring at the view out her bedroom window for a short while with her hair still damp.
examples.ja: シャワーの後、髪の毛が半乾きのまましばらく部屋の窓からの眺めを見つめていました。

meaning_mnemonic: 眺める is "to stare at." The noun version is <vocabulary>view</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary>. It's what you're staring at.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 眺める.

examples.en: I moistened a paper towel a little and wiped.
examples.ja: キッチンペーパーをちょっと湿らせて拭きました。

examples.en: Moistening a plant's roots before planting helps them settle into the soil.
examples.ja: 植物の根を湿らせてから植えると、土になじみやすいんですよ。

examples.en: To relieve even a little of the heat, I dampened a towel and wrapped it around my neck.
examples.ja: 少しでも暑さを和らげるために、タオルを湿らせて首に巻きました。

examples.en: Licking your lips to moisten them isn't good because it can actually dry them out instead.
examples.ja: 唇を舐めて湿らせることは、結局その後乾燥させてしまうことになりうるので、あまりいいことではありません。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 湿る is "to be moist"? This is the version where you're doing the moistening, making it <vocabulary>to moisten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dampen</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 湿る.

examples.en: This road is currently being paved.
examples.ja: この道は現在砕石舗装工事中です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Smash</kanji>ed <kanji>stone</kanji> is smashed stone. It's <vocabulary>rubble</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>broken stone</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My cousin fell and got a comminuted fracture in his left kneecap.
examples.ja: 私の従兄弟は、転んで左足の膝のお皿を粉砕骨折しました。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>powder</kanji> I will <kanji>smash</kanji> it! If I do that, it's <vocabulary>pulverization</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>smashing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Wow! That salesman is still talking to my mom. How persistent!
examples.ja: ええっ！あのセールスマンまだうちの母ちゃんと話をしてるよ。粘るね〜！

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sticky</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be sticky</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to persevere</vocabulary>, because if you're being sticky towards the situation, not giving up and not letting go. You're totally persevering by sticking around.
reading_mnemonic: Will I give up? I'll <reading>never</reading> (ねば) give up! I'll also never unstick from you.

examples.en: Are you thinking of buying some clay?
examples.ja: 粘土を買おうかなと思ってるの？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Sticky</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> is <vocabulary>clay</vocabulary>. Just think about feeling the clay. It's sticky especially when fresh and kind of wet, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why do you keep the adhesive tape in your jewelry box?
examples.ja: どうして粘着テープを宝石箱に仕舞っているの？

meaning_mnemonic:
If something <kanji>sticky</kanji> <kanji>wears</kanji> something else on it, it will stick together because there's <vocabulary>adhesion</vocabulary> between them.

粘着 refers to the adhesive properties of a material, especially in compound words like 粘着テープ (adhesive tape). On its own, it often describes the behavior of people who can't let go of a particular issue and keep on about it in unwanted ways.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My skin has gotten worse since I gave birth. What was that cosmetic brand you recommended before?
examples.ja: 出産後お肌の調子が悪くってさ〜。前に言ってたおススメの化粧品の名前教えてくれない？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Change</kanji> your face with <kanji>cosmetics</kanji>! This is via <vocabulary>makeup</vocabulary> or, of course, <vocabulary>cosmetics</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 化 is a new reading, け. To remember this, think about someone putting on <vocabulary>makeup</vocabulary>. They finish putting it on, and then you say "<reading>K, show</reading> (けしょう) me!"

examples.en: Takashi successfully deceived his girlfriend.
examples.ja: 孝志は彼女をうまく欺いた。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deceit</kanji>, so when you're doing deceit, you are going <vocabulary>to deceive</vocabulary> someone.
reading_mnemonic: As a human everyone would know who you are. You can't deceive anyone like that. But, <reading>as a moo</reading> (あざむ)... a cow is what I mean... nobody would know who you are.

examples.en: If you want to know various swindling tricks, you should ask Jenny.
examples.ja: 色々な詐欺の手口について知りたいなら、ジェニーに聞いたらいいよ。

examples.en: My grandmother was cheated out of one million yen in an imposter scam.
examples.ja: うちのお婆ちゃん、オレオレ詐欺にあって、百万円を騙し取られたんだ。

examples.en: Have you ever been accused of committing fraud?
examples.ja: 詐欺を働いて告訴された経験はおありですか。

meaning_mnemonic: If there are <kanji>lie</kanji>s and <kanji>deceit</kanji> in your interactions with people, you're committing <vocabulary>fraud</vocabulary>, you're carrying out a <vocabulary>scam</vocabulary>, you're <vocabulary>swindling</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My money was swindled by a forged title deed.
examples.ja: 私は偽の売買契約書で、お金を詐取されました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You use your <kanji>lie</kanji> to <kanji>take</kanji> what you want. That's when you <vocabulary>swindle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>defraud</vocabulary> someone to get their stuff. How dare you!

詐取 refers to the act of fraudulently obtaining something, typically money or property, through deceptive practices. This term is formal and often used in legal contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The gardener immediately recognized the misrepresentation of her age but didn’t say anything.
examples.ja: 庭師は彼女が年齢を詐称していることにすぐに気がつきましたが、何も言いませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>lie</kanji> about your <kanji>title</kanji>, the title which represents who you are, then that is a <vocabulary>misrepresentation</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>false statement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: On the day of Tanabata it was foggy in the morning, but it cleared up by noon.
examples.ja: 七夕の日、朝は霧がかかっていましたが、お昼には晴れました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading of the vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: My home stay father explained the Black Mist Scandal to me at dinner tonight.
examples.ja: ホームステイ先のお父さんが、今日の夕飯の際に黒い霧事件について説明をしてくれました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>fog</kanji> is going to be a really <vocabulary>thick fog</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>black veil</vocabulary> that covers suspicious acts or crimes. It's not a literal cloud of fog or a physical veil, it's what you hide your bad deeds in, metaphorically speaking.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 黒い and 霧.

examples.en: At a charity auction I made a successful bid on an incredibly beautiful painting of mountains breaking through the morning fog.
examples.ja: チャリティーオークションで、朝霧から山々が浮き出ている素晴らしく美しい絵を落札しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Morning</kanji> <kanji>fog</kanji> is <vocabulary>morning fog</vocabulary>, because it's fog in the morning. This is the best kind of fog, I think.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with both kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: I like the willow design on that Izakaya restaurant’s curtain.
examples.ja: あの居酒屋の柳模様の暖簾が好きなのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>willow</kanji> you have outside is a naggy willow, always asking for more water. That's <reading>yah naggy</reading> <vocabulary>weeping willow</vocabulary>.

examples.en: He’s a famous author of red-light district novels.
examples.ja: 彼は花柳小説の有名な著者ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>willow</kanji> for some reason is a <vocabulary>red light district</vocabulary>. Just imagine a shady red light district, and right in the middle is a flowering willow.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Could you write your senryu here?
examples.ja: ここにあなたの川柳を書いてもらえませんか？

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>river</kanji> of <kanji>willow</kanji>s... so hilarious! What a great <vocabulary>comic haiku</vocabulary>, that one is. Try to think of a comic haiku about the river willow, if you can.

The River Willow
Flows upstream like a salmon
This is not funny
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. And for once the kanji 川 doesn't use the kun'yomi reading. When you think of a <vocabulary>comic haiku</vocabulary>, think of something hilarious... like a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん), doing a standup act with a comedy haiku.

examples.en: You should go see the Ise Shrine once.
examples.ja: 伊勢神宮には、一度行ってみた方がいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The place with <kanji>Italy</kanji> <kanji>force</kanji> is a place known as <vocabulary>Ise</vocabulary>. It's a region of Japan that has a nice peninsula, I think. Going straight to the reading for this one may be your best bet.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out, because this uses the せ, not the せい you're used to seeing.

examples.en: Of all the food served during the Japanese New Year, datemaki is one of my favorites.
examples.ja: 伊達巻きはおせち料理の中で私が好きなものの一つです。

examples.en: Oh, so those were just fashion glasses? I had always assumed they had prescription lenses in them.
examples.ja: え、それって伊達眼鏡だったんですか？てっきり度が入ってるんだと思ってました。

examples.en: Haha, I haven't been living in Japan just for show. If it's Japanese at this level, you can leave it to me.
examples.ja: あはは、伊達に日本で生活はしてないですよ。これくらいの日本語なら任せてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
What does <kanji>Italy</kanji> <kanji>attain</kanji> like no other? <vocabulary>Flamboyance</vocabulary>! They redefine <vocabulary>chic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>stylishness</vocabulary>, dazzling everyone with their unabashed display.

This word isn’t just about fashion; it's also for flamboyant, attention-grabbing actions. While it's an old-fashioned word, you still find it in phrases like 伊達眼鏡 (fashion glasses) or 伊達に〜はしていない (not doing something for show).
reading_mnemonic:
The readings for both kanji are ones you haven't seen before. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

So how does Italy attain its <vocabulary>flamboyance</vocabulary>? Because it embodies <reading>Da</reading>n<reading>te</reading>’s (だて) bold essence—vibrant, captivating, and <vocabulary>chic</vocabulary> in every way. In Italy, Dante's influence is a living testament to flamboyant elegance.

examples.en: I worked as an assistant in the Tofugu sales department.
examples.ja: 私はトーフグ営業部の補佐として働きました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>supplement</kanji> of <kanji>help</kanji> is an <vocabulary>aid</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>help</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assistance</vocabulary>. Not a full on help, but an aid of sorts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m looking forward to meeting the colonel.
examples.ja: 大佐にお会いできるのを楽しみにしています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>help</kanji> is a <vocabulary>colonel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>navy captain</vocabulary>. They go around the seas, helping people in need by fighting the bad guys.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The lieutenant insisted on buying the colonel a drink.
examples.ja: その少佐は、大佐に飲み物を奢ると言ってきかなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>few</kanji> who <kanji>help</kanji> are the <vocabulary>major</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>lieutenant commander</vocabulary>s. They are the few who step up to the plate to help out in the army, according to this word's kanji.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The lieutenant colonel decided against immigrating to Japan.
examples.ja: 中佐は、日本への移住に反対することを決めた。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>help</kanji> in the army or navy is the <vocabulary>lieutenant colonel</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>navy commander</vocabulary>. I'm guessing these ranks are kind of in the middle or middle high end of the ranking scales?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I made a two square foot dog house for our Chihuahua.
examples.ja: うちのチワワに二平方尺の犬小屋を作ってあげました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Could you help me get my chest measurement with this tape measure?
examples.ja: この巻尺で胸囲を測るのを手伝ってもらえませんか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>scroll</kanji> of <kanji>shaku</kanji>. So, a scroll is all rolled up, right? And a shaku is an older form of Japanese measurement. If you roll up a measuring thing into a scroll-like container... what does it become? A <vocabulary>tape measure</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 巻 is the 巻く reading, pushed into the kanji. The 尺 reading is the normal reading of 尺. Careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: I pity them because they don’t have enough food, clothing, or shelter.
examples.ja: 衣食住もままならない彼らの事を哀れに思います。

meaning_mnemonic: If something is <kanji>pathetic</kanji> then you should have <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary> on it. You should also feel a little <vocabulary>sorrow</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grief</vocabulary> for it, because seriously, so pathetic!
reading_mnemonic: You look at the thing you're feeling is so pathetic that you feel <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary> for and just think... <reading>aww</reading> (あわ), that's really pathetic.

examples.en: I somehow feel sorry for people who only drink socially.
examples.ja: お酒を付き合い程度にしか飲まない人のこと、なんだか可哀想だなって思うんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>possible</kanji> <kanji>pathetic</kanji> scenario you might <kanji>imagine</kanji> is probably not just possibly pathetic. It's downright <vocabulary>pitiful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pathetic</vocabulary>, for sure.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Well, at least most of it does. To remember the reading for 哀 imagine some <vocabulary>pathetic</vocabulary> person who lost their home. They may be <vocabulary>pitiful</vocabulary> but at some point after losing their home they decided that the hood of your car would make a fine place to live. You can't help but ask them, "<reading>Why</reading> (わい) my car?" There are so many other cars this pathetic person could be camping out on, but they chose yours.

examples.en: The poodle, whose bacon had been taken away, was whining with a voice full of sorrow and grief.
examples.ja: ベーコンを取り上げられたプードルは、悲哀と悲しみに満ちた声でクーンクーンと鳴いていました。

meaning_mnemonic: I am <kanji>sad</kanji> and <kanji>pathetic</kanji> in how I feel. Such a deep <vocabulary>sorrow</vocabulary>! Such <vocabulary>grief</vocabulary> from my sad pathetic feelings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You say you have an inferiority complex about your pouty lips, but I find them really cute.
examples.ja: たらこ唇にコンプレックスを感じるって言うけど、僕は君の唇、とっても可愛いと思うよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Even though the baby was wearing cotton mittens, he still scratched his lower lip.
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんは、木綿のミトンをしていたにも関わらず、下唇を引っ掻いてしまった。

examples.en: "I can’t eat out this week because I’m broke." Hitomi said, biting her bottom lip.
examples.ja: 「お金が無いから、今週は外食出来ないの。」と言って、瞳は下唇をかんだ。

examples.en: The bottom lip of the ancient shark Helicoprion is just amazing. You should Google it!
examples.ja: 古代鮫ヘリコプリオン、とにかく下唇がすごいから、一度ググってみて！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>bottom</kanji> <kanji>lip</kanji> is your <vocabulary>lower lip</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bottom lip</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: したくちびる just combines the kun'yomi vocab reading for 下 and the kun'yomi reading you learned with the kanji for 唇.

examples.en: When I’m tired my upper lip usually swells.
examples.ja: 疲れると、上唇がよく腫れちゃうんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>above</kanji> <kanji>lip</kanji> is the <vocabulary>upper lip</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 上 is a bit weird, it's うわ instead of うえ. It's almost like うえ, just a little different.

examples.en: I want to know how much concrete-block wall installation will cost.
examples.ja: ブロック塀の取付け費用がいくらかかるのかが知りたいんですが。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I’m calling to let you know that I noticed someone climbing up your mud wall.
examples.ja: あなたの家の土塀をよじ登っている人がいたので、それをお知らせするためにお電話させて頂きました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>soil</kanji> <kanji>fence</kanji> is a fence made from soil. Usually this is in the form of a <vocabulary>mud wall</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>earthen wall</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: My iPhone captured the moment that the military plane shot down the helicopter.
examples.ja: iPhoneで軍事飛行機がヘリコプターを撃墜する瞬間を撮影しました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>attack</kanji> that causes a <kanji>crash</kanji> is when you're <vocabulary>shooting down</vocabulary> something, usually an aircraft.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you think that jet crashed due to human error?
examples.ja: あのジェット機の墜落は人為的ミスが原因だったと思う？

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>crash</kanji> and <kanji>fall</kanji> then you're <vocabulary>crashing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>falling</vocabulary>, or maybe both.

墜落 refers to falling from a height and ending with a crash, like an airplane or a satellite plummeting to the ground.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A Vitamin B1 deficiency might cause beriberi.
examples.ja: ビタミンB1が欠如すると、脚気になるかもしれないですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>lack</kanji> <kanji>likeness</kanji> to anything out there. You totally <vocabulary>lack</vocabulary> something that gives you likeness. It's a <vocabulary>deficiency</vocabulary>, or something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There is a reason for her sudden accusations of sexual harassment.
examples.ja: 彼女が突如彼をセクハラで訴え始めたのには理由があります。

meaning_mnemonic:
When something bears a <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>likeness</kanji>, we say it happens <vocabulary>suddenly</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>all of a sudden</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is relatively formal and somewhat literary.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That old woman will never approve of gambling.
examples.ja: あの老婆は絶対に賭博を認めようとしないんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>old woman</kanji> is just an <vocabulary>old woman</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I am so sorry for your loss. Your grandmother was such a nice lady that I always wished she was with me instead of your grandfather. Sadly, my wish never came true.
examples.ja: この度は本当にご愁傷様です。あなたのお婆さんはとても素敵な人だったので、あなたのお爺さんの代わりに私が一緒にいられればいいのにといつも願っていたほどですよ。残念ながら願いは叶いませんでしたがね。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>old woman</kanji>, even with an honorific and an お is still an <vocabulary>elderly woman</vocabulary>. She might be your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary> as well, though, so be nice!
reading_mnemonic: Even if she is your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary>, something is wrong. You look closely at her face. She's a sheep! <reading>Baa!</reading> (ばあ).

examples.en: Of course my phone had no reception at the edge of the cliff.
examples.ja: 崖っぷちではさすがに携帯圏外だったわ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

examples.en: It seems that somebody put a dish cloth on top of the pole instead of the national flag of Japan.
examples.ja: 誰かが棒のてっぺんに、日の丸の代わりに布巾をはためかせたみたいですね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cloth</kanji> <kanji>towel</kanji> is just a cloth towel. Essentially it's known as a <vocabulary>dish cloth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tea towel</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I called Koichi trying to sell him our dust cloth, but he didn’t want anything to do with me.
examples.ja: コウイチに雑巾を売り込もうと電話を掛けたんだけど、全く相手にされなかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>miscellaneous</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dust cloth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>house cloth</vocabulary>. It's just a cloth that you use on random things.
reading_mnemonic: The reading of 雑 is different from what you've learned. Instead of ざつ it's ぞう. Just imagine using this <vocabulary>dust cloth</vocabulary> to wipe down a <reading>象</reading> (ぞう). Its trunk is particularly dusty.

examples.en: The other day I met this ridiculously big man named Fugu in the ocean and he was wearing something that looked like a top hat, you know that kind of hat?
examples.ja: こないだ海でフグって名前のめちゃくちゃ大きい男に会ったんだけど、その人シルクハットみたいな帽子被っててさぁ、…あ、そういう感じの帽子、分かる？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hat</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cap</vocabulary>. Sadly, it's not made from children, unless you're crazy.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m actually a collector of old coins.
examples.ja: 私は実は、昔の貨幣の収集家なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>freight</kanji> of <kanji>cash</kanji> comes in. What is a freight of cash? It's just <vocabulary>money</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>currency</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>coinage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Whenever I go to America I feel like I’m rich with all the money in my wallet. Though, they are all one dollar bills.
examples.ja: アメリカに行くと、お財布に紙幣がギッシリ入るのでお金持ちになった気がするんですよね。まあ、それは全部一ドル札なんですが。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Paper</kanji> <kanji>cash</kanji> is <vocabulary>paper money</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 紙 even though you went through all that trouble to learn the kun'yomi reading. Did you know <vocabulary>paper money</vocabulary> is made of <reading>shee</reading>p (し)? Well, part sheep, but there's sheep in there for sure. That's why you can wash your paper money with your t-shirts in the washing machine.

examples.en: Why do you have a grudge against that stuntman?
examples.ja: どうしてあのスタントマンを恨んでいるんだい？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grudge</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hold a grudge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Who do you hold a grudge against the most? That would be <reading>you, Ra</reading> (うら). You and your dumb sun.

examples.en: I made a mistake I regret and ended up asking him for advice.
examples.ja: 痛恨のミスをしてしまい、彼にアドバイスしてもらうはめになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>pain</kanji> <kanji>grudge</kanji> is pain you feel from the grudge. I wish I could change my grudge. It is my <vocabulary>regret</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I hated my mom and she hated me just the same.
examples.ja: 私は母を憎んだが、母も同様に私のことを憎んでいました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hate</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to detest</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: What do you hate and detest more than anything? <reading>肉</reading> (にく). That stuff is gross, and you detest it.

examples.en: I can’t control these mixed feelings of love and hate anymore.
examples.ja: この愛憎の入り混じった気持ちをコントロールするのはもう無理だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have <kanji>love</kanji> and <kanji>hate</kanji> then you have <vocabulary>love and hate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why don’t we rest for a bit in this hut?
examples.ja: この山小屋でちょっと憩わないか。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rest</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to relax</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: I'm going <vocabulary>to rest</vocabulary> and play some <reading>Ico</reading> (いこ) on the ol' PlayStation.

examples.en: Have you ever thought about taking a break?
examples.ja: 今までに、休憩を取ることを考えたことはありますか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rest</kanji> <kanji>rest</kanji> is a <vocabulary>rest</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>break</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>recess</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m wearing too many layers and it’s so hot. Could you fan me?
examples.ja: 重ね着しすぎてすごく暑いんだけど、ちょっと私に向かって扇いでくれない？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>folding fan</kanji> and since you don't "to folding fan" something, this word means <vocabulary>to fan</vocabulary> instead.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine yourself trying <vocabulary>to fan</vocabulary> yourself with an <reading>青</reading> (あお) fan. For some reason blue fans feel cooler. Maybe it's because they're the color of ice/water?

examples.en: The only thing I could hear was the sound of the clock ticking and the whirring of the electric fan.
examples.ja: 時計のチクタクという音と、扇風機のブーンという音しか聞こえなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>folding fan</kanji> <kanji>wind</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is a machine that blows wind like a folding fan. That's an <vocabulary>electric fan</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>electronic fan</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: I bought this folding fan on special.
examples.ja: この扇子は特価で買ったんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>folding fan</kanji>'s <kanji>child</kanji> is, for some reason, a <vocabulary>folding fan</vocabulary>. I'm guessing there are different sizes of folding fans, and this is the smaller more manageable kind you can carry around easily and make it smaller by folding it up, which is why it's the "child" version of the folding fan. Still a folding fan, though.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've seen the す reading for 子 before, but here's a mnemonic just in case: 

Think about how you accidentally fanned some sweat droplets into a dude's face when you fanned yourself a little too hard with a <vocabulary>folding fan</vocabulary>, causing him to <reading>sue</reading> (す). Sued for a folding fan faux pas?! Americans really are litigious...

examples.en: Hey, this isn't funny! Open the door!
examples.ja: おい、ふざけている場合か！扉を開けろ！

meaning_mnemonic:
Like the kanji, this means <vocabulary>door</vocabulary>.

You've already learned 戸 (door), but 扉 is a bit different. While 戸 can refer to any kind of door (though often sliding ones), 扉 more specifically refers to a <vocabulary>hinged door</vocabulary>, including things like gates or panels that open on hinges.

Because 扉 evokes the image of a door that swings open, it's also sometimes used metaphorically. For example, a book's front page can be called a 扉, and you'll see expressions like 心の扉 (the door to one's heart) too.
reading_mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, so you know it'll probably use the kun'yomi reading. Fortunately, that's the とびら reading you learned with the kanji!

examples.en: When I was waiting in front of the gate, someone cut in front of me.
examples.ja: 私が門扉の前で待っていると、誰かが割り込んできました。

meaning_mnemonic:
What are <kanji>gate</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji>s? The <vocabulary>doors of a gate</vocabulary>, though we may still just call them a <vocabulary>gate</vocabulary> in English.

門扉 is a formal word you'll encounter more often in writing or architecture talk. It usually refers specifically to the part of the gate that slides or swings open (in other words, its doors).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses on'yomi readings. You've learned the もん reading for 門, but you haven't seen the ひ reading for 扉 yet (plus, it gets changed to ぴ in this word). Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that rendaku'd reading:

The <vocabulary>doors of a gate</vocabulary> often smell like <reading>pee</reading> (ぴ). Why? Dogs and drunks alike love to pee against <vocabulary>gate</vocabulary>s, that's why.

examples.en: According to him, she draws illustrations for books.
examples.ja: アイツの話によると、彼女、本の挿絵を描いてるんだってさ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>insert</kanji> a <kanji>picture</kanji> into a book, it becomes a <vocabulary>book illustration</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading used for 挿絵 is an exceptional one. Instead of そう it's さし. When you think of a <vocabulary>book illustration</vocabulary>, think of an illustration of a <reading>sash</reading>. Just picture after picture of a sash. Purple sashes. Green sashes. Flashy sashes. What a weird book, that only has illustrations of sashes.

絵, however, is the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that.

examples.en: There's an interesting anecdote about this.
examples.ja: これには、面白い挿話があるんですよ。

examples.en: If you have any anecdotes about the creation of WaniKani, please share.
examples.ja: ワニカニが出来るまでの、ちょっとした挿話があれば教えてください。

examples.en: One particularly amusing episode in "I Am a Cat" is the part where the cat eats mochi for the first time.
examples.ja: 『吾輩は猫である』の中で特に面白い挿話は、猫が初めて餅を口にする場面です。

examples.en: The charm of this novel lies in the heartwarming vignettes woven in between the main storyline.
examples.ja: この小説の魅力は、本筋の合間に織り込まれた心温まる挿話にある。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Insert</kanji> some extra <kanji>talk</kanji>ing into a story, and you have a <vocabulary>side story</vocabulary>!

挿話 is a relatively formal word that refers to a short <vocabulary>anecdote</vocabulary> or little <vocabulary>episode</vocabulary> inserted into a story that isn't essential to the main narrative but adds some additional context, background, or flavor.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why don’t we insert Aya’s illustration between these paragraphs?
examples.ja: このパラグラフの間にアヤのイラストを挿入するのはどうでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>insert</kanji> and <kanji>enter</kanji> something, you are doing <vocabulary>insertion</vocabulary> to it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I bought a small, palm-sized electronic dictionary.
examples.ja: 掌サイズの小さな電子辞書を買いました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>palm</kanji>, and so does the vocab! This is your <vocabulary>palm</vocabulary>, as in the <vocabulary>palm of one's hand</vocabulary>.

Something to note here is that you'll typically see "palm" in Japanese written as 手のひら. This kanji isn't as common but it does still mean the same thing.
reading_mnemonic:
Where is your <vocabulary>palm</vocabulary>? It's on your <reading>手のhere</reading> (てのひら). Right here. I point to your palm and say, "your hand here, that's where your palm is."

Another noteworthy thing about this kanji is it can be read as たなごころ. You won't see it read this way as often though so we're only teaching you the main reading.

examples.en: The train conductor apologized to the passengers for keeping them waiting.
examples.ja: 車掌は、乗客たちを待たせていることについて、お詫びをした。

meaning_mnemonic: Who drives a <kanji>car</kanji> with their <kanji>palm</kanji>? The 車 here actually comes from 電車, which is a train, making this person a <vocabulary>train conductor</vocabulary>. If you think about it, conducting a train involves a lot more palm action because of all those levers and knobs and big buttons, right? Yeah, let's go with that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You probably haven’t noticed, but president Koichi holds absolute power.
examples.ja: 恐らく気づいていないと思うが、コウイチ大統領は全てを掌握しているんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Put something in your <kanji>palm</kanji> and <kanji>grip</kanji> it. Now it's in your grasp — you're <vocabulary>grasping</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The blood dripped from his forehead.
examples.ja: 彼の額から、血が滴り落ちました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drip</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to drip</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To drip</vocabulary> drip drip on your head... what's dripping on your head? You're standing below a toilet that's leaking. The dripping sounds like "<reading>sh*t, ta-ta</reading> (したた), with each drip making a "ta" sound because it's kind of thick and poopy.

examples.en: Water droplets are beading on the car windows.
examples.ja: 車の窓には水滴がついています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>drip</kanji> is a <vocabulary>drop of water</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>water drop</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: After getting an IV drip, he was thoroughly examined.
examples.ja: 点滴を受けた後、彼は綿密な診察を受けました。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Point</kanji> <kanji>drip</kanji>s are drips coming down little by little. These are the drips of an <vocabulary>intravenous drip</vocabulary>. 

Back in the day this was a way of talking about raindrops, or really any falling drops of water. But nowadays we only use it for <vocabulary>IV drip</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ve been busy, but I do cook for myself. In fact, last night I made a stewed vegetable dish called ratatouille.
examples.ja: 忙しいけど、ちゃんと自炊してるよ。実際、昨日の夜はラタトゥイユっていう野菜の煮込み料理を作ったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>cook</kanji> is <vocabulary>cooking for oneself</vocabulary>. Better break out the TV tray.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We hired a man to do kitchen work.
examples.ja: 僕たちは、炊事をする男を雇った。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>cook</kanji>ing <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is just the act of <vocabulary>cooking</vocabulary>. It's the <vocabulary>kitchen work</vocabulary>. 

炊事 refers to tasks involved in meal preparation as part of everyday life. It's a relatively formal word and not as commonly used as 料理, but you might see it used in lists of household chores or duties, like in a job description for a housekeeper.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We are all looking forward to Takeshi buying a rice cooker.
examples.ja: 私達はみんな、剛志が炊飯器を買うのを楽しみにしています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cook</kanji> <kanji>food</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> is a container used to cook the main food staple in Japan. In this case it's a <vocabulary>rice cooker</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The fresh ocean breeze felt good on my skin.
examples.ja: 爽やかな海の風が肌に心地よかった。

examples.en: When I opened the box, the fresh scent of pineapple filled the room.
examples.ja: 箱を開けると、パイナップルの爽やかな香りが部屋に広がった。

examples.en: Putting on my favorite dress always lifts my spirits.
examples.ja: お気に入りのワンピに袖を通すと、いつも気分が爽やかになる。

examples.en: A fresh-faced hunk passed by me and I had to do a triple-take.
examples.ja: 爽やかなイケメンが横を通り過ぎたので、思わず三度見をしちゃいました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is the noun version of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary> as well.

爽やか generally describes something light, pleasant, and uplifting. You can use it for things like a cool morning breeze, the refreshing scent of fruit, or even a person who gives off a clean-cut and charming impression.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same reading you learned with the kanji!

examples.en: This ten and a half mat room for just 10,000 yen a month is a first come, first served deal.
examples.ja: 10.5畳で毎月のお家賃が一万円のこの部屋は、早い者勝ちの物件です。

examples.en: The four-and-a-half-tatami room was just the right size for their love back then.
examples.ja: 四畳半の部屋は、その頃のふたりの愛にはちょうどいい広さだった。

examples.en: Even if there's no tatami, if you say "rokujō hitoma," it still conveys an idea of the room's size.
examples.ja: 畳の部屋でなくても、「六畳一間」と言えば大体の広さが伝わります。

examples.en:
Tatami mats come in different sizes such as "Edo-ma," "Kyo-ma," and "Danchi-ma," so even a 6-tatami room can vary in actual size.
If you're not aware of this, you might run into problems like thinking "It's 6 tatami, but it feels small" or "The 6-tatami carpet doesn't fit."
examples.ja: 畳には「江戸間」「京間」「団地間」などのサイズがあり、同じ6畳でも広さがちがいます。これを知らないと、「6畳なのにせまい」「6畳のカーペットが合わない」などのトラブルが起こることがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The 〜 shows the number of tatami mats, and the 畳 part is "tatami" of course. So, this is a <vocabulary>counter for tatami mats</vocabulary>. It is generally used to show how big an apartment or something is. Oh, your apartment is 12 tatami mats? Nice and big!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I found his inside out, wrinkled dress shirt on the tatami where he threw it.
examples.ja: 私は畳の上に脱ぎ捨てられた、表裏が逆になった皺々のワイシャツを見つけました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes right from the vocab meaning, which is <vocabulary>tatami mat</vocabulary>. The たたみ part, specifically.

examples.en: As one would expect from a veteran announcer like her, she answered the question in an easy to understand, clear voice.
examples.ja: さすがベテランアナウンサーなだけあって、彼女はとてもよく聞き取れる明瞭な声でその質問に答えました。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>bright</kanji> and <kanji>clear</kanji> has great <vocabulary>clarity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clearness</vocabulary>. Just look at something with such brightness and such clearness! It has so much clarity!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Word of mouth spread rapidly and the foldable ceramic chopsticks became really popular.
examples.ja: 口コミがあっという間に広がって、その折りたたみ式の陶器のお箸はとても人気が出ました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: The streets were decorated with chopsticks to welcome the Japanese prime minister.
examples.ja: 日本の首相を歓迎するために、通りは割り箸で飾られました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Divide</kanji>able <kanji>chopsticks</kanji> are chopsticks you can split apart. They are <vocabulary>splittable chopsticks</vocabulary>, almost always made from wood of some kind.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 割る and 箸 put together. Be careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: In a kendo match, Koichi hit the lower part of the opponent’s torso perfectly with his bamboo sword.
examples.ja: 剣道の試合で、コウイチは竹刀で相手の胴を完璧に討ち取りました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: You have the longest torso I’ve ever seen.
examples.ja: 君は今までみた中で一番胴体が長いよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>torso</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> is the body area that's your torso. It's your <vocabulary>body</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>trunk</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>torso</vocabulary>, depending on what kind of body you have.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I bought one hundred cases of HB mechanical pencil lead because they were at a bargain price.
examples.ja: お買い得だったので、HBのシャー芯を百ケース買いました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>wick</kanji> and this word also means <vocabulary>wick</vocabulary>, but it means things at the <vocabulary>core</vocabulary> of other long things more often. Things like <vocabulary>pencil lead</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>marrow</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: There was a beautiful rainbow above the fluttering Japanese flag.
examples.ja: はためく日本国旗の上には、美しい虹が掛かっていた。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I purchased rainbow colored wasabi but it tastes just like regular wasabi.
examples.ja: 虹色の山葵を購入してみたんですが、味はまんま山葵ですね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Rainbow</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji>ed things are <vocabulary>rainbow colored</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kanji readings for both 虹 and 色.

examples.en: Isn’t the manager’s daughter a wannabe singer?
examples.ja: 部長のお嬢さんは確か歌手志望じゃなかったですっけ？

meaning_mnemonic:
Adding an お in front and a さん behind <kanji>miss</kanji> makes for a very respectful way of addressing a<vocabulary>young lady</vocabulary>. It can also be used to refer to somebody’s <vocabulary>daughter</vocabulary> in a polite manner.

Note that older generations tend to use this word to directly address a young woman. But be careful when doing this yourself, as it might come across as overly formal!
reading_mnemonic: The reading of 嬢 is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

examples.en: You shouldn’t wear slippers barefoot if you don’t want to get athlete’s foot.
examples.ja: 水虫になりたくないなら、スリッパを裸足で履かない方がいいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>naked</kanji> <kanji>foot</kanji>, it means you're not wearing anything on your foot, making you <vocabulary>barefoot</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading here is a bit weird. It's like the words 裸 (はだか) and 足 (あし) were smushed together into one word. The 裸 becomes はだ and the 足 becomes し. You can think of it this way: You were <vocabulary>barefoot</vocabulary> too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you <reading>had ashi</reading> (はだし) at one point in the past.

examples.en: Our earnings aren’t very high, so I keep a budget account book to look at our spending habits in order to save money.
examples.ja: 稼ぎがそんなに多くないので、何によくお金を使っているか習慣を見直して節約するために家計簿をつけています。

meaning_mnemonic: 稼ぐ is "to earn income." This is the noun version. It's just <vocabulary>earnings</vocabulary>, the things you earn.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 稼ぐ.

examples.en: The lookout platform we use for deer hunting is covered in a big blue tarp now.
examples.ja: 鹿狩り用の見張り台は、今は大きなブルーシートで覆われています。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 狩り is hunting already. This is the same thing (<vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>). Difference is this one is attached to other words to specify what kind of hunting you're doing.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the same as 狩り, but since it follows another word, it gets rendaku-ed. Here is a mnemonic to help with remembering the rendaku.

Hunting can be <reading>girly</reading> (がり), if you dress up like a girly hunter.

examples.en: "Why don’t you brush your teeth?" "Because I like how the taste of food stays in my mouth! What’s so wrong with that?!
examples.ja: 「どうして歯を磨かないの？」「だって、食べ物の味が口に残っているのが好きなんだもん。それっていけないことかしら？」

meaning_mnemonic: 磨く is "to polish" or "to shine." If you're doing that to your <kanji>teeth</kanji> you are brushing them. That's why this is <vocabulary>to brush one's teeth</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 歯 and 磨く, put together.

examples.en: I'm in the middle of something. I'll come back later and make the muddy water clear.
examples.ja: 今立て込んでるんだ。後で戻ってきてから泥水を澄ますよ。

examples.en: I strained my ears to hear the faint but constant screeching coming from upstairs.
examples.ja: 私は、一つ上の階からコンスタントに聞こえてくる気味の悪い金切り声を聞くために、耳を澄ましました。

examples.en: The Major kept a composed face even when the Colonel was angry with him.
examples.ja: 少佐は、大佐に怒られても澄ました顔をしていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
澄む is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you <reading>mus</reading>t (ます) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is or <vocabulary>to make something clear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to clear something</vocabulary>.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to strain</vocabulary> when used together with 耳, as in 耳を澄ます, "to strain one's ears".
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so if you know that, that'll make this answer clear too.

examples.en: I’ve recently been playing a game called Katamari Damacy.
examples.ja: 最近は塊魂というゲームをプレイしています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>lump</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> is the lump of spirit that's used in the famous game <vocabulary>Katamari Damacy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 塊 and 魂 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: But, why did the hackers aim the brunt of their attack at us?
examples.ja: でも、どうしてハッカーは攻撃の矛先を俺たちに向けてきたんだ？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>spear</kanji> <kanji>ahead</kanji> is the most ahead part of the halberd. That's the <vocabulary>point of spear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>spearpoint</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab versions of 矛 and 先 combined together.

examples.en: Thanks to your taking care of my kid, Ms. Date, I could do my shopping freely.
examples.ja: 伊達さんがうちの子を見ていてくれたお陰で気兼ねなく買い物ができました。

examples.en: Because of the down quilt that my parents gave me, it’s really hard to get out of bed these days.
examples.ja: 両親がプレゼントしてくれた羽毛布団のお陰で、最近布団から出るのがかなり辛い。

examples.en: Thanks to everyone, we could go to the quarter-finals of the Japan National High School Baseball Tournament held in Koshien stadium.
examples.ja: 皆様のお陰で、我々は甲子園球場で開催されている高校野球のトーナメントで、準々決勝にまで進出することができました。

meaning_mnemonic:
陰 is a shadow, and adding お to it and makes it honorific. It becomes the shadow of someone very important, and means <vocabulary>thanks to</vocabulary>, as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." This originally comes from the idea of being in the shadow of the gods, who are protecting you and helping you out!

If that's hard to remember, think about shade helping you out. Perhaps <vocabulary>thanks to</vocabulary> the <kanji>shade</kanji> you were able to survive the heat of the desert.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word 陰. <vocabulary>Thanks to</vocabulary> that other vocab word, you can read this one!

examples.en: I removed my dog’s ear wax with a cotton swab and it was kind of sticky. Is it normal?
examples.ja: 綿棒で犬の耳垢を取ったら何だか粘々していたんですが、それは普通ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Sticky</kanji> <kanji>sticky</kanji> things are really <vocabulary>sticky</vocabulary> and covered with <vocabulary>stickiness</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 粘る. I suppose you <reading>never never</reading> want to touch something <vocabulary>sticky</vocabulary>.

examples.en: These are rice crackers, a souvenir from Tokyo.
examples.ja: これは東京土産の煎餅です。

examples.en: Green tea always goes well with senbei.
examples.ja: やっぱり煎餅には煎茶が合うよね。

examples.en: Viet got annoyed and threw the rice crackers.
examples.ja: ビエトは苛々して煎餅を投げた。

meaning_mnemonic: What do you get when you <kanji>roast</kanji> <kanji>mochi</kanji>? <vocabulary>Senbei</vocabulary>, a crispy Japanese <vocabulary>rice cracker</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for the second kanji, but if you remember the meaning of the word, that will get you to the reading. In case you're having trouble, here's a mnemonic to help:

You sit eating <vocabulary>senbei</vocabulary> next to a <reading>bay</reading> (べい), looking out over the water as you crunch.

examples.en: I made green tea. Would you like some?
examples.ja: 煎茶を入れたので良かったら飲みませんか。

examples.en: I love Starbucks' sencha green apple tea.
examples.ja: スタバの煎茶グリーンアップルが大好きなんです。

examples.en: My big brother pours green leaf tea over pancakes.
examples.ja: 私の兄はホットケーキに煎茶をかけて食べるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>roast</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji>, you get <vocabulary>green tea</vocabulary>, also known as <vocabulary>green leaf tea</vocabulary>or <vocabulary>sencha</vocabulary>.

In reality there are various ways to make green tea, but for the purposes of this mnemonic, let's imagine it's always roasted!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There was an image of Buddha carved into the stone.
examples.ja: その石には仏像が彫ってありました。

examples.en: In front of this historic shrine, there's a gate with a swan carved on it.
examples.ja: この由緒ある神社の前には、白鳥が彫られた門がある。

examples.en: At the factory, I'm in charge of engraving text using an engraving machine.
examples.ja: 工場で、彫刻機を使って文字を彫る仕事を担当しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carve</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to carve something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to engrave something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it can take a direct object. You engrave letters into a stone, and you carve a scary face into a pumpkin. Those letters and that face are your objects.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine trying <vocabulary>to carve something</vocabulary> using a <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ). Its long handle makes it a pretty impractical tool for carving. Now imagine all the trouble you have carving with it.

examples.en: Asphalt is gravel that's hardened with petroleum.
examples.ja: アスファルトは、砂利を石油で固めたものなんですよ。

examples.en: The uranium mine is at the end of this gravel road.
examples.ja: ウラン鉱山はこの砂利道の先にあります。

examples.en: I think it would be a shame to spread gravel over the garden when we could grow vegetables.
examples.ja: 折角野菜を育てられるのに、庭に砂利を敷いてしまうのはもったいないと思うんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji>sand</kanji> makes a lot of <kanji>profit</kanji>, it swells up and becomes <vocabulary>gravel</vocabulary>. They're like the fat cats of the beach.
reading_mnemonic:
You learned the reading for 利 with the kanji, but the reading for 砂 is irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're walking through that big fat <vocabulary>gravel</vocabulary>, when a pile of it starts moving, and something suddenly leaps out at you. It's a... <reading>ja</reading>guar (じゃ)! Run!

examples.en: How's your dad?
examples.ja: お前の親父さん、元気？

examples.en: That bearded dude is really stubborn.
examples.ja: あのヒゲ親父、ホント頑固なんだから。

examples.en: I grew up watching my dad's back from a young age.
examples.ja: 俺は小さい頃から、親父の背中を見て育った。

meaning_mnemonic:
One's <kanji>parent</kanji> <kanji>father</kanji> is simply just <vocabulary>one's father</vocabulary>. 

Note that 親父 has a masculine and somewhat vulgar tone to it. It can refer to your own dad, someone else's, or a <vocabulary>middle-aged man</vocabulary> you're friendly with. When not talking about your own father, you'll want to add a さん at the end, making it 親父さん.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is unfortunately a bit of an exception. 親 uses the kun'yomi おや, and 父 uses the じ reading which you learned with 叔父. You've learned all these readings before, so as long as you remember them, you're good to go. If you don't, check out the mnemonics for these readings on their vocabularies' pages!
